docs.lead_paragraph: A 38-year-old woman in northeastern Bahia State gave birth to a boy weighing 16.7 pounds, a ''giant baby,'' in the words of one doctor. ''Obviously, the baby was born by Caesarean section,'' the director of the Albert Sabin Maternity Hospital said. Doctors said the baby's size was probably a result of his mother's diabetic condition.

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: 'Giant' Baby Boy

docs.abstract: Albert Sabin Maternity Hospital, Bahia State, Brazil, director announces that 38-year-old woman has delivered 16.7 pound baby boy (S)
docs.snippet: A 38-year-old woman in northeastern Bahia State gave birth to a boy weighing 16.7 pounds, a ''giant baby,'' in the words of one doctor. ''Obviously, the baby was born by Caesarean section,'' the director of the Albert Sabin Maternity Hospital said....

docs.lead_paragraph: SARU JAYARAMAN has good reason to be pleased. She is the executive director of the Restaurant Opportunities Center of New York, a little nonprofit that just pulled off a David-versus-Goliath feat. The center extracted $164,000 from two fashionable Manhattan restaurants -- Cité and the Park Avenue Cafe -- to settle lawsuits that involved charges of discrimination and failure to pay overtime to 23 restaurant employees, most of whom are immigrants from Mexico and Bangladesh. The center was born out of the ashes of the World Trade Center to help the surviving employees of Windows on the World, and it has grown into a muscular advocacy group for restaurant workers citywide.

headline.main: For the Kitchen Help, She Stands the Heat

docs.abstract: Public Lives interview with Saru Jayaraman, director of Restaurant Opportunities Center of New York; photo; small nonprofit group got Cite and Park Avenue Cafe to settle lawsuits over alleged discrimination and failure to pay overtime to 23 employees, mostly immigrants from Mexico and Bangladesh; center itself plans to open restaurant, Colors, on Lafayette Street, to be owned and run by workers; Jayaraman is daughter of Indian immigrants who graduated from Yale Law School and Harvard's Kennedy School of Government (M)
docs.snippet: Saru Jayaraman is the executive director of the Restaurant Opportunities Center of New York, a little nonprofit that just pulled off a David-versus-Goliath feat.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: RESTAURANT OPPORTUNITIES CENTER OF NEW YORK

docs.lead_paragraph: SUSAN N. WILSON, a large gold necklace with the words SEX, ETC. dangling around her neck, is having wheat toast without any butter for her birthday breakfast. The necklace, a retirement gift from her staff, looks as if it should be adorning a rap artist or someone who uses words like bling-bling rather than a 75-year-old who lives in Princeton and shops at Ann Taylor.

headline.main: Sex Ed Without Birds, Bees or Even Storks

docs.abstract: Public Lives interview with Susan N Wilson, New Jersey's most visible activist for sex education; Wilson, 75, was coordinator of Network for Family Life Education at Rutgers and was instrumental in establishing sex education curriculum in public schools (M)
docs.snippet: Susan N. Wilson is New Jersey's most visible activist for sex education.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel recommended against the over-the-counter sale of a Merck cholesterol-lowering drug, saying that while millions of Americans could benefit from taking it, they should not begin such a regimen without a doctor's advice. The F.D.A. typically heeds such recommendations, meaning that the drug industry has been at least temporarily thwarted from creating a new segment of the drug market. But Merck and its partner in the application, Johnson & Johnson, said they would continue trying to win approval.

headline.main: F.D.A. Panel Votes Against Sale of Statins Over Counter

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration advisory panel recommends against over-the-counter sale of Merck & Co's cholesterol-lowering drug Mevacor, saying that while millions of Americans could benefit from taking it, they should not begin such regimen without doctor's advice; Merck and its partner in application, Johnson & Johnson, say they will continue trying to win approval (M)
docs.snippet: The panel said that while Americans could benefit from taking a Merck cholesterol-lowering drug, they should not begin such a regimen without a doctor's advice.
